title: If I marry someone who owes back taxes, will I be responsible for that money?
question: My fiance is worried if we get married that my wages will be garnished because he owes back taxes. I do not own a home, but will they will freeze my assets?
question_tags: Small business taxes,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Tax law
answers: The other attorneys have given you good, practical advice. I would add you should keep your wages in a separate account so that when they try to attach his assets, you will still be able to reach your money. Best solution, of course, is to deal with this. If there is doubt as to liability or collectibility, an offer in compromise might be a good idea as a way to resolve the issue. He may be able to settle for pennies on the dollar. Use the AVVO.com web site to find a tax attorney in your area. In addition to that, contact your local bar association for referral to an attorney who specializes in this. Often, but not always, the attorney will do an initial consultation free of charge. You will then be in a better position to determine what to do next. Best of luck to you!

Although you may not be responsible for "back taxes" please keep in mind that the various taxing authorities will attempt to attach any of his/her wages, bank accounts or assets, which could make your life difficult. So, you may consider seperating "your" money in a seperate banking account (different bank) and prepare your budget in the event that the taxing authorities attach his/her accounts and assets....and, yes, your fiance will want to take care of this problem sooner rather than later...and a good tax attorney will be very valuable.

No, you will not be directly liable for the back taxes. Separate debts remain separate debts following marriage. The IRS cannot freeze your assets. Of course, after you get married, you should not file joint tax returns.

You are not responsible for someone else's tax before you marry. Otherwise, it would be a restraint against marraige which would be unconstitutional.

However, the risk is that, if the IRS perceives that you and fiance earn more than enough income to meet daily needs, they may garnish his wages and look to you to provide more support. It all depende on your income versus his.

If you are worried, do not file a joint return with him, because any refunds generated will be kept by the IRS. If you file separate, you will get your refunds back.
